Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


I'm not trying to say I know how a spirit could record on an analog record=
er, or if they can at all: my point was that it wasn't reasonable to assume=
 it could directly change the bits on digital media and wind up with anythi=
ng usable.

But, were I to conjecture, one might say that the air pressure =
of a voice is converted to a signal that modifies the magnetic properties o=
f a tape.=C2=A0 And a line recording uses a signal, not from the mic, but f=
rom some other source, to do the same.=C2=A0 So if that signal were to be m=
anipulated via external EMF, it would change the final result on the tape.=
=C2=A0 

Since we are also assuming that digital recorders can pick up spir=
its, then the simplest explanation is that that same up-front signal (befor=
e it gets digitized into bits) is also being manipulated.=C2=A0 And an EMF =
source could theoretically manipulate both the analog tape signal, and the =
digital tape signal.

However, it may be that an EMF source strong enough t=
o modify the signal would also effect all kinds of other things in the unit=
, including the final media itself.=C2=A0 It would be interesting for someo=
ne to determine what kind of external EMF is needed to induce or modify a s=
ignal in the pre-digital phase of the recording circuitry, and what side ef=
fects that would have.=C2=A0 Depending on the result, it could either revea=
l other ways to detect spirit influence, or prove that no spirit influence =
(via EMF) is happening.

      Your points seems to be that yo=
u can make it work without 
        knowing how it works.=C2=A0 So we need =
to talk about what you mean by 
        that.

When you use the microphone,=
 you just speak, and let the 
        recorder do the rest.=C2=A0 In this c=
ase, you are using the recorder 
        without really knowing how it work=
s. =C2=A0 If a spirit can manipulate 
        the EMF field around the AtoD=
 converter (even without using the mic), 
        then they should be able =
to do the same: just use it without knowing how 
        it works: the reco=
rder does the rest.=C2=A0 In neither case do either of 
        you need to=
 know how it works, to get it to work. I am not questioning 
        this.
=

But, if they are going to change the bits on the actual 
        media the=
mselves, then they must know how it works, it order to get all 
        tho=
se bit-things I mentioned right.=C2=A0 The recorder can't "do the 
        =
rest", because by changing the bits on the media themselves, they are 
    =
    going completely around what the recorder does, and doing the details 
=
        themselves.=C2=A0 And as I said, the details there are very technic=
al, 
        and include things like converting their words into digital sa=
mples of 
        groups of a specific number of bits in a specific format =
on specific 
        places in specific orders with other specific other bi=
ts connected to 
        them like file ownership and dates and such.=C2=A0=
 It is the job, 
        basically, of a computer, not a person.

If they a=
re changing the 
        bits on the media, then the recorder is not doing =
that.=C2=A0 They are 
        no longer letting the recorder "do it", like =
you or they would be if 
        they just used it normally.=C2=A0 The reas=
on you can "make it work" 
        without understanding it, is because the=
 recorder is doing the work for 
        you.=C2=A0 If they are to change t=
he media directly, then the recorder 
        is no longer doing the work, =
and so they must understand all those 
        digital issues.

So that is =
the difference between being able to 
        use it without understanding =
it, and not being able to use 
        it.

Manipulating EMF is one 
                         =
   thing.=C2=A0 But directly storing bits on a media is 
                  =
          way beyond that.=C2=A0 Bits are not stored in a 
                =
            continuous stream.=C2=A0 They are broken into bytes 
          =
                  (little packets) that is totally controlled by the 
     =
                       processor and software.=C2=A0 For Elvis to "encode 
=
                            directly" to the media, he would have to do wha=
t 
                            that software does to the digital signals co=
ming in 
                            from the AtoD converter: he would have=
 to group the 
                            bits into (for example) 16 littl=
e herds each, decide 
                            on the specific bit inter=
pretation scheme (2's 
                            complement?) ,=C2=A0 fin=
d space on the media, update 
                            the media's dicti=
onary of where there is free space 
                            and where t=
here isn't, link the herds together with 
                            some =
sort of linked pointer, skip around the areas 
                            =
marked 'bad' on the media, update things like 
                            =
date/time modified and size, respect any kind of 
                         =
   ownership permissions on the media, and so 
                            =
on.

It is much more credible for the signal 
                            t=
o be manipulated near the AtoD converter (where EMF 
                      =
      changes would have the most straighforward result) 
                 =
           than in the digital media itself.

<table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0" ><tr><td valign=3D"=
top" style=3D"font: inherit;"><br>I'm not trying to say I know how a spirit=
 could record on an analog recorder, or if they can at all: my point was th=
at it wasn't reasonable to assume it could directly change the bits on digi=
tal media and wind up with anything usable.<br><br>But, were I to conjectur=
e, one might say that the air pressure of a voice is converted to a signal =
that modifies the magnetic properties of a tape.  And a line recording=
 uses a signal, not from the mic, but from some other source, to do the sam=
e.  So if that signal were to be manipulated via external EMF, it woul=
d change the final result on the tape.  <br><br>Since we are also assu=
ming that digital recorders can pick up spirits, then the simplest explanat=
ion is that that same up-front signal (before it gets digitized into bits) =
is also being manipulated.  And an EMF source could theoretically
 man=
ipulate both the analog tape signal, and the digital tape signal.<br><br>Ho=
wever, it may be that an EMF source strong enough to modify the signal woul=
d also effect all kinds of other things in the unit, including the final me=
dia itself.  It would be interesting for someone to determine what kin=
d of external EMF is needed to induce or modify a signal in the pre-digital=
 phase of the recording circuitry, and what side effects that would have.&n=
bsp; Depending on the result, it could either reveal other ways to detect s=
pirit influence, or prove that no spirit influence (via EMF) is happening.<=
br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Wed, 5/20/09, April Abercrombie <i><april@aberc=
rombieghostresearch.com></i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style=3D"border-l=

onverting their words into digital samples of

rder

ng able to

td valign=3D"top"><br>Manipulating EMF is one 
                            =
thing.  But directly storing bits on a media is 
                     =
       way beyond that.  Bits are not stored in a 
                   =
         continuous stream.  They are broken into bytes 
             =
               (little packets) that is totally controlled by the 
        =
                    processor and software.  For Elvis to "encode 
   =
                         directly" to the media, he would have to do what 
=
                            that software does to the digital signals comin=
g in 
                            from the AtoD converter: he would have to=
 group the 
                            bits into (for example) 16 little h=
erds each, decide 
                            on the specific bit interpre=
tation scheme (2's 
                            complement?) ,  find s=
pace on the media, update 
                            the media's dictiona=
ry of where there is free space 
                            and where ther=
e isn't, link the herds together with 
                            some sor=
t of linked pointer, skip around the areas 
                            mar=
ked 'bad' on the media, update things like 
                            dat=
e/time modified and size, respect any kind of 
                            =
ownership permissions on the media, and so 
                            on.=
<br><br>It is much more credible for the signal 
                          =
  to be manipulated near the AtoD converter (where EMF 
                   =
         changes would have the most straighforward result) 
              =
              than in the digital media itself.<br><br>--- On
